   59yoF admitted with AMS, sepsis from obstructed renal stone s/p perc
   nephrostomy, cardiomyopathy likely from hypothyroidism as well as
   respiratory failure likely from acute lung injury.  Now with improving
   cardiac and renal function, but persistently altered mental status and
   new focal ileus.
   #. Altered mental status
 Mental status improving, now able to follow
   commands, but very aggitated when not sedated.  Agitated on precedex,
   so we are using fentanyl/versed.  When she is awake she is severely
   agitated with signs of possible delirium.  MRI showed no acute
   process.  Further work-up will have to wait for when her lung process,
   pancreatitis and fevers have improved.  West Nile virus negative
   --Appreciate neurology recs.  However, patient is not taking POs and
   can therefore not receive Seroquel.  We will hold off on a psychiatry
   consult until her other issues have improved.
   --Continue Haldol 1mg TID.
   #. Pancreatitis/ileus
Pancreatitis is most likely secondary to the
   Propofol, as the CT abdomen [**9-27**] showed no signs of cholelithiasis.
   She is having continued fevers and now has increasing pleural
   effusions.  We will get a abdominal CT to assess for the extent of the
   pancreatitis and possible fluid collection.
   --No contrast abdominal CT.
   --She will go today for post-pyloric dobhoff placement by IR.
   --Continue TPN until she is getting adequate tube feeds.
   #.  Fevers/leukocytosis
Continued fevers and slight rise in
   leukocytosis today.  We had been attributing this inflammation to
   pancreatitis, but there is still concern for infection, especially
   considering her worsening CXR.  Could there be infection of the
   pericardial fluid?  The pulmonary effusions are not large enough for a
   diagnostic tap. Currently only on Cipro to cover Klebsiella in urine.
   Blood cx, urine cx and c.diff negative to date.
   --Repeat blood, urine and sputum cultures for source of new
   leukocytosis.
   --F/u cultures and outstanding serologies
   --Continue with Ciprofloxacin. Today is day 9 of cipro and day 13/14 of
   fluroquinolones.
   --Continue to follow CXRs.
   #. Respiratory failure
Continues to require assist control and CXR
   looks worse today.  It is unclear what process is going on in her
   lungs, whether she continues to have a concurrent, multi-focal
   pneumonia that is incompletely covered with cipro, or if she is now
   developing ARDS.
   --Continue to follow daily CXR
   --Wean ventilatory settings as tolerated.
   #.  Cardiomyopathy and Pericardial Effusion
Unclear why the pericardial
   effusion is increasing on CXR.  We had been attributing the effusion to
   hypothyroidism, but if it is increasing while he is receiving
   levothyroxine, we may need to search for another etiology. Last echo
   showed that EF had improved to 40% and stable effusion without
   tamponade physiology.  All viral cultures negative to date.
   - Re-consult cardiology for possible drainage of pericardial fluid or
   repeat echo.  Will repeat echocardiography tomorrow.
   #. Hypothyroidism with elevated TPO
On thyroid replacement.  Per
   endocrine, not likely Hashimoto
s encephalopathy.
   --Continue levothyroxin to 50 IV qday
   --repeat TFTs in [**3-3**] wks
   #. Pyelonephritis
Pulled out perc nephrostomy tube and had it replaced.
   Cultures positive for pan sensitive Klebsiella.  On Cipro day 8 (13/14
   of fluroquinolones).  Still draining ~300ccs per day from the
   nephrostomy tube.
   -- Continue for total 14d course of Cipro
   -- Will need reimaging if the future per ID recs to assess for abscess
   -- Will eventually need stone and drain removed eventually.
   #. Anemia
Hematocrit is currently stable.  Most likely cause of anemia
   is marrow suppression in the setting of sepsis, compounded by frequent
   blood draws.
   --Continue to trend Hct daily.
   --Transfuse for Hct<21.
   #. DM2
Off of lantus, getting insulin with TPN and on regular sliding
   scale every 6 hours.
   #. FEN:
   - Currently NPO and receiving TPN because of ileus.  Will restart tube
   feeds once dobhoff is in place.
   - Dobhoff in IR
   #. PPX
   - Pneumoboots and SC heparin.
   - bowel regimen
   - H2 blocker for ulcer prophylaxis (famotidine)

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- Patient is a 59-year-old female admitted with altered mental status (AMS) and sepsis from obstructed renal stones post-percutaneous nephrostomy.
- She has a history of cardiomyopathy likely due to hypothyroidism as well as respiratory failure likely from acute lung injury.
- The patient's mental status is improving, but she remains agitated and shows signs of possible delirium.
- MRI shows no acute process, and further work-up will have to wait until her other issues improve.
- Pancreatitis is most likely secondary to Propofol, as the CT abdomen showed no signs of cholelithiasis.
- She has continued fevers and increasing pleural effusions, with a worsening CXR.
- The patient continues to require assist control ventilation, and her respiratory failure persists.
- Her cardiomyopathy and pericardial effusion are ongoing concerns.
- She has hypothyroidism with elevated TPO, for which she is receiving thyroid replacement therapy.
- The patient had pyelonephritis caused by pan-sensitive Klebsiella, for which she is being treated with Cipro.
- Anemia is likely due to marrow suppression in the setting of sepsis.
- She has diabetes mellitus type 2.
- The patient is currently NPO and receiving TPN due to ileus. She will restart tube feeds once a dobbhoff is in place.
- She is on various medications including Haldol, Cipro, and TPN.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Altered mental status: The patient continues to have altered mental status, which may be due to delirium or another underlying cause. Further evaluation and management are needed.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient has pancreatitis, likely secondary to Propofol. Close monitoring of pancreatic enzymes and symptoms is necessary. Continued treatment of the underlying cause is essential.
3. Fevers and leukocytosis: The patient has persistent fevers and leukocytosis, suggesting an ongoing infection. Blood, urine, and sputum cultures should be repeated to identify the source of infection. Antibiotic therapy should be adjusted accordingly.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient continues to require assist control ventilation, indicating unresolved respiratory failure. Close monitoring of respiratory status and weaning of ventilatory settings as tolerated is necessary.
5. Cardiomyopathy and pericardial effusion: The patient has ongoing cardiomyopathy and pericardial effusion. Further evaluation, including echocardiography, is needed to determine the cause and appropriate management.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism

Based on the information provided in the progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient:

1. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has imbalances in potassium (K+), sodium (Na+), and chloride (Cl-) levels, which need to be monitored and corrected if necessary.

2. Delirium/confusion: The patient is experiencing altered mental status, which could be attributed to various factors such as prolonged sedating medications, toxic metabolic injury to the brain, hypothyroidism, or sepsis. It is important to continue evaluating and managing this condition.

3. Pancreatitis: The patient has acute pancreatitis, likely secondary to Propofol administration. Pancreatitis can lead to complications like necrosis, abscess formation, and systemic inflammation.

4. Ileus: The patient has developed focal ileus, which can result in bowel obstruction, distension, and decreased bowel movement. Monitoring the patient's bowel sounds and stool output is crucial.

5. Pyelonephritis: The patient had an episode of pyelonephritis, characterized by positive cultures for pan-sensitive Klebsiella. This infection can progress to kidney abscesses if not appropriately managed.

3. Fevers/Leukocytosis: The patient had low-grade temperature and white count decreased this morning. She is currently only on Cipro to cover Klebsiella in urine. Repeat blood, urine, and sputum cultures are needed to identify the source of new leukocytosis.
4. Pyelonephritis: The patient had a positive culture for pan-sensitive Klebsiella. She is

   59yoF admitted with several months of cognitive slowing and acute AMS,
   sepsis from obstructed renal stone s/p perc nephrostomy, cardiomyopathy
   likely from hypothyroidism as well as respiratory failure likely from
   multi-focal pneumonia.  Unclear main underlying cause.  Now
   persistently altered mental status with extreme agitation, continued
   respiratory failure and new pancreatitis.
   #. Altered mental status
 Mental status improving, now able to follow
   commands, but extremely agitated when not sedated.  Self-extubated
   twice yesterday.  Agitated on [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] we are using
   fentanyl/versed.  When she is awake she is severely agitated with signs
   of possible delirium.  MRI showed no acute process.  Further work-up
   will have to wait for when her lung process, pancreatitis and fevers
   have improved.  West Nile virus negative
   --Appreciate neurology recs.  However, patient is not taking POs and
   can therefore not receive Seroquel.  We will hold off on a psychiatry
   consult until her other issues have improved.
   --Continue Haldol 1mg TID.
   #. Pancreatitis/ileus
Pancreatitis is most likely secondary to the
   Propofol, as the CT abdomen [**9-27**] showed no signs of cholelithiasis.
   She is having continued fevers and now has increasing pleural
   effusions.  We will get a abdominal CT to assess for the extent of the
   pancreatitis and possible fluid collection.
   --No contrast abdominal CT.
   --She will go today for post-pyloric dobhoff placement by IR.
   --Continue TPN until she is getting adequate tube feeds.
   #.  Fevers/leukocytosis
Continued fevers and slight rise in
   leukocytosis today.  We had been attributing this inflammation to
   pancreatitis, but there is still concern for infection, especially
   considering her worsening CXR.  Could there be infection of the
   pericardial fluid?  The pulmonary effusions are not large enough for a
   diagnostic tap. Currently only on Cipro to cover Klebsiella in urine.
   Blood cx, urine cx and c.diff negative to date.
   --Repeat blood, urine and sputum cultures for source of new
   leukocytosis.
   --F/u cultures and outstanding serologies
   --Continue with Ciprofloxacin. Today is day 9 of cipro and day 13/14 of
   fluroquinolones.
   --Continue to follow CXRs.
   #. Respiratory failure
Continues to require assist control and CXR
   looks worse today.  It is unclear what process is going on in her
   lungs, whether she continues to have a concurrent, multi-focal
   pneumonia that is incompletely covered with cipro, or if she is now
   developing ARDS.
   --Continue to follow daily CXR
   --Wean ventilatory settings as tolerated.
   #.  Cardiomyopathy and Pericardial Effusion
Unclear why the pericardial
   effusion is increasing on CXR.  We had been attributing the effusion to
   hypothyroidism, but if it is increasing while he is receiving
   levothyroxine, we may need to search for another etiology. Last echo
   showed that EF had improved to 40% and stable effusion without
   tamponade physiology.  All viral cultures negative to date.
   - Re-consult cardiology for possible drainage of pericardial fluid or
   repeat echo.  Will repeat echocardiography tomorrow.
   #. Hypothyroidism with elevated TPO
On thyroid replacement.  Per
   endocrine, not likely Hashimoto
s encephalopathy.
   --Continue levothyroxin to 50 IV qday
   --repeat TFTs in [**3-3**] wks
   #. Pyelonephritis
Pulled out perc nephrostomy tube and had it replaced.
   Cultures positive for pan sensitive Klebsiella.  On Cipro day 8 (13/14
   of fluroquinolones).  Still draining ~300ccs per day from the
   nephrostomy tube.
   -- Continue for total 14d course of Cipro
   -- Will need reimaging if the future per ID recs to assess for abscess
   -- Will eventually need stone and drain removed eventually.
   #. Anemia
Hematocrit is currently stable.  Most likely cause of anemia
   is marrow suppression in the setting of sepsis, compounded by frequent
   blood draws.
   --Continue to trend Hct daily.
   --Transfuse for Hct<21.
   #. DM2
Off of lantus, getting insulin with TPN and on regular sliding
   scale every 6 hours.
   #. FEN:
   - Currently NPO and receiving TPN because of ileus.  Will restart tube
   feeds once dobhoff is in place.
   - Dobhoff in IR
   #. PPX
   - Pneumoboots and SC heparin.
   - bowel regimen
   - H2 blocker for ulcer prophylaxis (famotidine)

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old female who was admitted with cognitive slowing, acute altered mental status (AMS), sepsis from obstructed renal stone, cardiomyopathy likely from hypothyroidism, and respiratory failure likely from multi-focal pneumonia. The main underlying cause is unclear. The patient continues to have persistent fevers, altered mental status with extreme agitation, continued respiratory failure, and new-onset pancreatitis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status has been improving but she remains agitated when not sedated. She self-extubated twice yesterday. Agitation and signs of possible delirium are present. Further work-up will have to wait for when her lung process, pancreatitis, and fevers have improved.

2. Pancreatitis/ileus: The patient has developed pancreatitis likely secondary to Propofol. She is also experiencing a persistent ileus. A non-contrast abdominal CT showed no signs of cholelithiasis. She will undergo a post-pyloric Dobhoff placement by IR and continue total parenteral nutrition (TPN) until she is able to tolerate tube feeds.

3. Fevers/leukocytosis: The patient continues to have fevers and a slight rise in leukocytosis today. Blood cultures, urine cultures, and c.diff negative to date. Repeat blood, urine, and sputum cultures are pending for the source

   59yoF admitted with several months of cognitive slowing and acute AMS,
   sepsis from obstructed renal stone s/p perc nephrostomy, cardiomyopathy
   likely from hypothyroidism as well as respiratory failure likely from
   multi-focal pneumonia.  Unclear main underlying cause.  Now
   persistently altered mental status with extreme agitation, continued
   respiratory failure and new pancreatitis.
   #. Altered mental status
 Self-extubated twice yesterday.  We are
   using fentanyl/versed because she was persistently agitated on precedex
   and propofol caused pancreatitis.  It is hard to assess if the haldol
   has helped.  When she is awake she remains severely agitated with signs
   of possible delirium.  MRI showed no acute process.  She was in acute
   distress when extubated and has an impressive ongoing process in her
   lungs, so she needs to remain intubated for now, preventing us from
   weaning further.
   --Appreciate neurology recs.  Now that the patient has a dobhoff in
   place, we can consider changing him over to Seroquel [**Hospital1 7**] instead of
   Haldol with risperdal for acute agitation.
   #.  Fevers/leukocytosis
It remains unclear why the patient has
   low-grade fevers.  They may be caused by the pancreatitis, but her
   abdominal CT was not particularly impressive.  Could there be infection
   of the pericardial fluid?  Cardiology does not think that is a likely
   source and are not keen on a diagnostic pericardiocentesis.  She has
   evidence of pulmonary infection, though it is unclear how that ties in
   with her overall picture.  The pulmonary effusions are not large enough
   for a diagnostic tap.  She has completed a course of ciprofloxacin (14
   days of quinolones), and as we do not have another source of
   infections, we will stop antibiotics for now, and culture for fevers.
   --Repeat blood, urine and sputum cultures if she spikes a fever again.
   --If she continues to be febrile today, will consult ID in AM tomorrow.
   --F/u cultures and outstanding serologies
    --Continue to follow CXRs.
   #. Pancreatitis/ileus
Pancreatitis is most likely secondary to the
   Propofol.  There were no signs of severe pancreatitis or complications
   on CT scan.  Per radiology there is no clear radiologic evidence of
   pancreatitis.  The plan for now is supportive care.  It is difficult
   for us to assess whether the pancreatitis is improving or worsening.
   --Start tube feeds by post-pyloric dobhoff.
   #. Respiratory failure
Yesterday when extubated she maintained good O2
   sats, but was in tachypneic and in distress, mouthing that she could
   not breath.  Her CXR looks slightly improved today.  We will try a
   trial of pressure support, to assess whether she can be weaned further.
   --Continue to follow daily CXR
   --Wean ventilatory settings as tolerated.
   #.  Cardiomyopathy and Pericardial Effusion
Unclear why the pericardial
   effusion is increasing on CXR.  We had been attributing the effusion to
   hypothyroidism, but if it is increasing while he is receiving
   levothyroxine, we may need to search for another etiology. Last echo
   showed that EF had improved to 40% and stable effusion without
   tamponade physiology.  All viral cultures negative to date.
   - Re-consult cardiology for possible drainage of pericardial fluid or
   repeat echo.  Will repeat echocardiography tomorrow.
   #. Hypothyroidism with elevated TPO
On thyroid replacement.  Per
   endocrine, not likely Hashimoto
s encephalopathy.
   --Continue levothyroxin to 50 IV qday
   --repeat thyroid panel tomorrow, per endocrine recommendations.
   #. Pyelonephritis
Pulled out perc nephrostomy tube and had it replaced.
   Cultures positive for pan sensitive Klebsiella and has completed a
   course of cipro.  Still has adequate drainage (~500ccs per day) from
   the nephrostomy tube.
   -- d/c cipro today
   -- Will need reimaging in the future per ID recs to assess for abscess.
   -- Will eventually need stone and drain removed.
   #. Anemia
Hematocrit drop this morning, repeat draw is pending.  Has
   slowly been drifting down, which have attributed to marrow suppression
   in the setting of sepsis, compounded by frequent blood draws.
   --f/u PM crit.
   --Transfuse for Hct<21.
   #. DM2
Off of lantus, getting insulin with TPN and on regular sliding
   scale every 6 hours.
   #. FEN:
   - Will continue TPN until she is getting enough tube feeds to support
   her nutritionally.
   - replete lytes PRN
   #. PPX
   - Pneumoboots and SC heparin.
   - bowel regimen
 has mushroom tube in today to allow for bowel
   movements.

   59yoF admitted with several months of cognitive slowing and acute AMS,
   sepsis from obstructed renal stone s/p perc nephrostomy, cardiomyopathy
   likely from hypothyroidism as well as respiratory failure likely from
   multi-focal pneumonia.  Unclear main underlying cause.  Now
   persistently altered mental status with extreme agitation, continued
   respiratory failure and new pancreatitis.
   #. Altered mental status
 We are using fentanyl/versed because she was
   persistently agitated on precedex and propofol caused pancreatitis.
   Haldol switched to Seroquel yesterday.  When she is awake she remains
   severely agitated with signs of possible delirium.  MRI showed no acute
   process.
   --Wean sedation as tolerated.
   #.  Fevers/leukocytosis
It remains unclear why the patient has
   low-grade fevers.  They may be caused by the pancreatitis, but her
   abdominal CT without obvious source.    Cardiology does not think that
   is a likely source and are not keen on a diagnostic
   pericardiocentesis.  The pulmonary effusions are not large enough for a
   diagnostic tap.  She has completed a course of ciprofloxacin (14 days
   of quinolones) for pyelonephritis, and as we do not have another source
   of infections, we will stop antibiotics for now, and culture for
   fevers.
   - Consult ID
   - F/u cultures and outstanding serologies
   #. Pancreatitis/ileus
Pancreatitis is most likely secondary to the
   Propofol.  There were no signs of severe pancreatitis or complications
   on CT scan.  Per radiology there is no clear radiologic evidence of
   pancreatitis.  The plan for now is supportive care.  It is difficult
   for us to assess whether the pancreatitis is improving or worsening.
   --Start tube feeds by post-pyloric dobhoff.
   #. Respiratory failure
Tolerated a trial of pressure support.
   --Wean ventilatory settings as tolerated.
   #. Anemia
Hct trending down without obvious source of bleeding.  Source
   likely marrow suppression in the setting of sepsis, compounded by
   frequent blood draws.  Platelets and coags stable, hemolysis unlikely
   and previous labs negative.  No iron studies in system.
   - transfuse 1 unit pRBC
   - guiac stools
   - iron studies
   - active type and screen
   - Transfuse for Hct<21.
   #.  Cardiomyopathy and Pericardial Effusion
Unclear why the pericardial
   effusion is increasing on CXR.  We had been attributing the effusion to
   hypothyroidism, but if it is increasing while he is receiving
   levothyroxine, we may need to search for another etiology. Last echo
   showed that EF had improved to 40% and stable effusion without
   tamponade physiology.  All viral cultures negative to date.
   - Re-consult cardiology for possible drainage of pericardial fluid or
   repeat echo.  Will repeat echocardiography tomorrow.
   #. Hypothyroidism with elevated TPO
On thyroid replacement.  Per
   endocrine, not likely Hashimoto
s encephalopathy.
   --Repeat TFTs pending
   --Continue levothyroxin to 50 IV qday
   #. Pyelonephritis
Pulled out perc nephrostomy tube and had it replaced.
   Cultures positive for pan sensitive Klebsiella and has completed a
   course of cipro.  Still has adequate drainage (~500ccs per day) from
   the nephrostomy tube.
   -- d/c cipro today
   -- Will need reimaging in the future per ID recs to assess for abscess.
   -- Will eventually need stone and drain removed.
   #. DM2
Off of lantus, getting insulin with TPN and on regular sliding
   scale every 6 hours.
   #. FEN:
   - Will continue TPN until she is getting enough tube feeds to support
   her nutritionally.
   - replete lytes PRN
   #. PPX
   - Pneumoboots and SC heparin.
   - bowel regimen
 has mushroom tube in today to allow for bowel
   movements.
   - H2 blocker for ulcer prophylaxis (famotidine)

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old female admitted with cognitive slowing, acute altered mental status (AMS), sepsis from obstructed renal stones post percutaneous nephrostomy, cardiomyopathy likely from hypothyroidism, and respiratory failure likely from multi-focal pneumonia. She has a prolonged hospital course, extreme agitation, continued respiratory failure, and new-onset pancreatitis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Altered mental status: The patient is likely delirious from a prolonged hospital course. She is minimally sedated and will be monitored closely. Psychiatric consultation has been requested.

2. Fevers/leukocytosis: The patient has low-grade fevers and leukocytosis with an unclear etiology. Pancreatitis and pyelonephritis are possible causes. Cultures will be followed, and further investigation is needed.

3. Pancreatitis/ileus: The patient developed pancreatitis possibly secondary to propofol. Supportive care is ongoing, and there is no clear evidence of severe pancreatitis or complications on the CT scan. Ileus is improving with increased bowel movement.

4. Anemia: The patient has iron deficiency anemia from chronic disease. She received a unit of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) yesterday. The cause of the anemia is unclear.

5. Cardiomyopathy and pericardial effusion: The patient has an unclear cause for the increasing pericardial
